tn.text: "Nisan" is the name of the first month of the Hebrew calendar. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_hebrewmonths]])

tn.ref: in the twentieth year of Artaxerxes the king
tn.text: "in the 20th year that Artaxerxes was king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Nehemiah tells background information about his demeanor before the king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"So the king"

tn.ref: Why is your face so sad
tn.text: Here Nehemiah is referred to by his face because the face shows one's emotions. AT: "Why are you so sad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: This must be sadness of heart
tn.text: This speaks of Nehemiah being sad as if his heart were sad, since the heart is often considered the center of emotions. AT: "You must be very sad" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Then I became very much afraid
tn.text: As Nehemiah prepares to answer, he is afraid because he does not know how the king will respond.

Nehemiah is showing honor to King Artaxerxes. Here "forever" is an exaggeration that refers to a long life. AT: "Long live the king!" or "May the king have a long life!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: Why should not my face be sad?
tn.text: Here Nehemiah uses this rhetorical question to tell the king that he has a reason to be sad. This can be written as a statement. AT: "I have very good reasons to be sad." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: the place of my fathers' tombs
tn.text: "the place where my ancestors are buried"

tn.ref: its gates have been destroyed by fire
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "fire has destroyed its gates" or "our enemy has burned its gates" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Then I replied to the king"
Nehemiah refers to himself this way to show his submission to the king.
Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. AT: "in your judgment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the city of my fathers' tombs
tn.text: "the city where my ancestors are buried"
Nehemiah does not plan to do all of the building himself, but he will be the leader of the work. AT: "that I and my people may rebuild it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: may letters be given to me
tn.text: This may be stated in active form. AT: "may you give letters to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is the name of the province that was west of the Euphrates River. It was across the river from the city of Susa.
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the good hand of God was on me
tn.text: God's "good hand" represents his "favor." AT: "God's favor was upon me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Sanballat is the name of a man, and the Horonites were a people group. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This man was likely a freed slave now serving as an officer in Ammon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"heard that I had arrived" (UDB)
Here Nehemiah's "heart" refers to his thoughts and will. AT: "had inspired me" or "had led me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: There was no animal with me
tn.text: "There were no animals with me"
A few men accompanied Nehemiah on this inspection, but he speaks in the first person because he was the primary person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: I went out by night by the Valley Gate
tn.text: "At night, I went out through the Valley Gate"
a wild dog
Presumably, refuse was removed from the city through this gate.

tn.ref: which had been broken open, and the wooden gates were destroyed by fire
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "which Israel's enemies had broken open, and the wooden gates which their enemies had destroyed with fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: So I went up ... and I turned back
tn.text: The other men with Nehemiah also followed him. AT: "So we went up ... and we turned back" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"through the Valley Gate"

tn.ref: the rest who did the work
tn.text: This refers to the men who would later rebuild the walls. AT: "the others who would later do the work of rebuilding the walls" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "you" is plural, referring to all the people mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:neh:02:15|02:16]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: its gates have been destroyed by fire
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "how our enemies destroyed its gates by fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: so we will no longer be in disgrace
tn.text: "so we will no longer be ashamed"

tn.ref: the good hand of my God was on me
tn.text: God's "good hand" represents his "favor." AT: "my God's favor was upon me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom. AT: "begin building" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: So they strengthened their hands for the good work
tn.text: The phrase "strengthened their hands" means to prepare to do something. AT: "So they prepared do this good work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These are the names of men. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:neh:02:09|02:9-10]]. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a man. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: What are you doing? Are you rebelling against the king?
tn.text: These rhetorical questions are used to mock Nehemiah. These can be written as statements. AT: "You are acting foolishly! You should not be rebelling against the king!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This refers to Artaxerses, the king of Persia.
This is an idiom. AT: "will begin rebuilding" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: But you have no share, no right, and no historic claim in Jerusalem
tn.text: "But you have no share, legal right, or religious claim to Jerusalem"
